Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research-Future Scientists Improving the Public's Climate Literacy: Engaging in Outreach Opportunities Incorporating Strategies From the Learning and Social Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration: The Lawrence Hall of Science and the Department of Geography and Center for Atmospheric Sciences at the University of California, Berkeley (UCB), in collaboration with Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO) and the University of Washington's (UW) Department of Atmospheric Sciences, are working to improve public climate literacy by designing and developing sessions for a new college course that includes an outreach practicum at a local informal science education institutions (ISEI), such as a museum, science center or aquarium. This course provides undergraduate and graduate students - future scientists - with cross-disciplinary knowledge of public climate literacy, how people learn, and how to engage in effective interactions with non-scientists. Students practice and apply their knowledge in a local ISEI, which serves to both increase the public's understanding of climate change and reinforce the student's understanding of climate science. The goals of this project are to: 1) develop the science communication skills of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as faculty, at UCB, SIO, and UW; 2) advance the public's climate literacy, including their understanding of climate change science, its social, political and economic contexts, and its impacts on their local environment and community, through the outreach efforts of the students in this course; and 3) serve as a model to improve cross-disciplinary dialog about climate change and climate literacy within universities, and develop partnerships between universities and their local ISEIs. This 18-month project includes collaborative development of multi-disciplinary college course sessions for a new course, Promoting Climate Literacy, which will be piloted by science faculty at the three collaborating universities and serve as a model for future dissemination efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is growing urgency for the public to understand climate change, and thus the field of public climate change education is rapidly growing. Promoting Climate Literacy is a university course that introduces graduate and undergraduate science students to effective active learning and engagement strategies and learning theory, while helping students to more deeply understand and better communicate their knowledge of climate science and climate change to the public. The Promoting Climate Literacy course (also called Communicating Climate Science) provides students exposure to cutting-edge research, case studies, and best practices that will prepare the next generation of scientists to contribute productively to this public need. The outreach experience provides students—future scientists—with confidence and a suite of strategies they can use to communicate their own research in the future: in the lecture hall, at scientific meetings, with the media, or in involvement with public outreach efforts.

Students taking Promoting Climate Literacy learn key climate science concepts relevant to understanding climate change; how people learn, behave, and make decisions; and how to use climate science and social science knowledge to practice communicating climate change to the public. The course was designed by the team that developed Communicating Ocean Sciences, offered in ~25 institutions across the country. This new course is important because one of the biggest challenges in climate change is how to communicate it effectively to the public.

College students have the opportunity to deepen their understanding of science concepts in profound ways through carefully crafted experiences to learn climate science alongside learning how learning happens, and through opportunities to grapple with explaining climate science concepts to the public. The course also provides a vehicle for: 1) ensuring that future scientists are prepared to be effective communicators and providers of broader impact activities, 2) helping science faculty to change the way they teach as they learn about and apply evidence-based pedagogy in their practice, 3) delivering climate change sciences experiences directly to the public, 4) promoting partnerships between scientists and science educators, and 5) improving the broader impact activities of scientists.

Promoting Climate Literacy materials include learning research based on how people learn and make decisions; climate science that revisits and reinforces students’ knowledge of relevant science ideas; opportunities for students to make connections and reflect on and relate to their own understanding, experiences, assumptions, and biases; and interactive activities for students to practice communicating climate science with their peers and the public. Specifically the course includes:

1)    12 fully described sessions which contain background information for the instructor about the learning, social and cognitive sciences addressed in the sessions; at-a-glance descriptions; timeframe; materials; student handouts; and a fully detailed session description with step-by-step instructions for the instructor on how to implement.

2)    Two types of slide presentations including science briefings focused on climate science topics designed with embedded active learning strategies; and session slides which follow the session write-ups and include discussion prompts, suggested homework, instructions for student activities etc.

3)    Climate science and climate change activities designed based on research about how people learn, for students to use for outreach.
